indicators.justification: The government websites for the Ministry of Environment and Housing and the Department Environmental Planning and Protection have no search function and no listed information about endangered species or ecosystems. Only the Bahamas National Trust has unstructured data in the form of factsheets on both. These sheets are over two decades old and documents its scientific name, local name, its features, reproduction, habitat and range, endangered status, threats, and interesting facts. There is no information on number of times and locations sighted or field studies.

indicators.justification:
The data is not available as structured data. Most are available in PDF documents that are reports compiled by the Department of Statistics (DoS). The DoS receives the data from the Registrar General Department (RGD) but the public cannot access any data except their personal information from the RGD. The information from the DoS website itself is available as Excel files but the information is severly limited, both in terms of specific characteristics of births and deaths and vital statistics information in general. The information in the reports are more complete and include:

(1) births and deaths by island but not regions or 
    districts

(2) births by the age, gender, marital status, and place of 
    birth of the mother but not father

(3) births by sex and month of birth of child

(3) deaths classified using International 
    Classification of the Causes of Death (ICD)

(4) death by age and sex

(5) infant mortality by type, age of death, island, and 
    cause of death

(6)  information on data limitations indicating when 
     statistics are provisional, revised, or not available

The data is available free of charge, in English, and there is no open license information. While not easy, it is possible to track changes in vital statistics over time. The data is dated suggesting that there is a problem with the production and/or publishing of the data.

indicators.justification:
The Ministry of Health website hosts daily bulletins that update individuals about infections and hospitalizations (1) but does not provide information about the number of beds  available, tests, vaccines, or devices. The Ministry does have the capacity to publish statistics because it does host reports (2) on hospital services (includes annual trends in hospital bed capacity). However, this capacity seems to be limited because the information posted by its Health Information and Research Unit is dated. Their most recent posting used statistics from 2017, so there is no information on COVID-19. Information about hospital capacity may be obtained directly from the Ministry, hospitals, and from news outlets (3). The website has information about the location of vaccination centres (4) but it seems this information is only updated when vaccines are available. Information about testing facilities is available online but this seems to be for tourism than public health (5).

indicators.justification:
A significant amount of information is available online about COVID-19 vaccination. The problem is that it is unstructured data in the form of text and as such requires some time to find and compile the information.   
The press releases from the website of the Office of the Prime Minister contain the most updated information on the progress of the COVID-19 vaccination campaign. For example, the press release from the National COVID-19 Vaccine Consultative Committee (May 23 (1) and April 20, 2021 (2)) documents the:

(1) total number of vaccines since the start of the 
    campaign (please note that this was March 14 2021) 
(2) number administered by island (major population 
    centres)
(3) percentage who received a dose by age group 
(4) days on which vaccinations took place and the 
    centres of vaccination 

The update (July 4, 2021 (3)) provides information on the:

(1) total number of doses that the government received 
    by type (all AstraZeneca) and source of vaccine
(2) total administered by the number of doses received 
    and island
(3) percentage of those who received the first dose 
    who received the second dose by island 

There seems to be no information by gender or national origin (no information on Haitian migrants).

The information seems to be updated regularly and it is possible to track the progress of vaccination over time.

(1) National COVID-19 Vaccine Consultative Committee Update, 2021. https://opm.gov.bs/remarks-national-covid-19-vaccine-consultative-committee-update/?highlight=National%20COVID-19%20Vaccine%20Consultative%20Committee

(2) Statement – Dr. Merceline Dahl-Regis, 2021. https://opm.gov.bs/statement-dr-merceline-dahl-regis-23-may-2021/?highlight=National%20COVID-19%20Vaccine%20Consultative%20Committee

(3) Vaccine Distribution and Supplies Statement, 2021. https://opm.gov.bs/press-release-vaccine-distribution-and-supplies-statement/?highlight=National%20COVID-19%20Vaccine%20Consultative%20Committee

indicators.justification:
The Bahamas National Geographic Information systems is a unit within the government that is responsible for providing public access to data on land usage. Unfortunately, it does not seem that data and metadata are available via the government website (1). The available data sets (e.g. from Stanford Earthworks) only show the administrative boundaries of the country (2). Forests can be identified as green areas on the map but these are not consistently labeled and as such a familiarity with the country or other sources would have to be consulted to be sure that those areas are forests. No information is available on land use or protected areas. It is possible to identify some of the protected areas on the maps by first finding them on the protected areas register (3).

(1) Map Publications (Public Domain). https://www.bahamas.gov.bs/wps/portal/public/map%20publication%20domain/map%20publications/!ut/p/b1/vZbbjqM4EIafZR4gg23AhEsIhKMdjglwgxIgBwghJCEQnn7Ssy3tzram-2JnQwkhS_Xrc_12lWASJmKS0_p-2K1vh-a0Pr6tE5y6MnB9W2QlTbAFYARCgC1DAViEzIqJkrgXlCvZqap_55rYv7ocR-rVIg4y7zRGiTXrm8rs04eG2mJLNe2yujjR7J6uVSRtqkyEM85gM5k6Nl2Q_dgc4t2xmLoT7zG20BEncjaH-NTP1Rsa9Mmk3c63UWYZpWdt7aUc1iMC96t9OAexd97qtnEs6PIqYPWqJlN90Vtt6qA-5YI6Oz8Lip8Fgd88EvisXl7m3_WfJLzpWaARSeKmROMBBkbo2JIj6GhK4bv-NwkLDvwn_VvCl-eVfIb4uYOfCZ9Z9CnE5b9AWIiJnwnCb130OCZgIsClfvk4G2M1eiUYCAmWjg8aAENISFgGNND6K51BX1EhqCANSs-gKgCkug5EVJx86YWypEB0fNCvgPyrgcKLgQJ6NRC-Gsi-GEhffUspfjXwz7eFySSHTf29z-rv4DuHIUIYYx4hjkMsZJZmdhhmjbRTDWWfoJq7bTqerg72su7MsJzLAa4UPEFBfceOPkSLPSi7nSFb1prdxvgWyPa55KRrc5pWUh0CVGyMOWhO82unPDgvCd0FAReHTXfReHtskjaZZHfF4s_RZXhsxfgbQ_WmLt5t-Xt-BUsADAgkz4cumHrggy2jDwMlBPRSAKiELAkvHg1rQGhOSWnaIAjhdZR6cnEBCUyD5Pq7LTN1TLLh38AFCsQncAaxFfLAB_z_DdT4xfQ5oYXAkXgEwIx9MdD_85b-ctPYKRSRCADmMYYiN2WWdtYPbz8tihHtW16R16mSVdjLreqcyX2lSO21umFxmUftNu10fsynDoxiRTaH8dJVxzXuZ4XadJKgwG7ndG5Mi9KVSzs8z9NioYcp0CwnElN9KyX0atehvdgclfSs7tEgrw_rdTAr2-NDmUADhMemR3lxPIjNLjUvn7clhh9Hq-ARMsaIjDIFZYj88LSkYfWg-QoS9Sl4M7JqBl9xn69Jbrfg3SxZueTQ_QKog1cD0auB_IuB4qstFf-8pb90GBJFEaEp5p9fjFhWYJZljAelIb2ieuneX5ZZkXTs9iofrfChzmQ_PnamPym3FNg5pso56CZVx5GF3nZtZAB4Owf-5KAhA-SlOOwa7dGZJiLPXfrsQqO6eVpVQBbr5eRAyqBP7-IQR-PKaxHeDXmh7TeZxe3n2lFNCjeVyrbOW7MRGpy5Y6oXl26m2_hoi2bSh664Kr1A3o9UsvHpMlCFgjvOHUd1YuGSOaQ8SKr07Rtzru-WZdnYU7f0Y3DryV-xGaN_xFP4A7x2h9Q!/dl4/d5/L2dBISEvZ0FBIS9nQSEh/

indicators.justification:
Detailed land tenure information is largely unavailable as open data.  It is possible to obtain some information from Registrar General's database. For example, the instrument data form (1) provides some indication of the information that is available with deeds (e.g., the name of the company or person submitting the deed, the type of document, contact information) (2). More complete information (including maps) can be obtained by writing directly to the Registrar General's office ((3).

indicators.justification:
The information on the The Annual Budget website is available as PDF files (therefore, not structured data) and interactive graphics but no datasets are available (1). There are data for the graphics that can be downloaded as CSV files but this is just the information used to produce a specific graph (2). The usable data are in the PDF reports. The PDF documents contain proposed, amended, and approved budget information with international classifications including administrative, economic, function, and programme (3).

Sources

(1) The Annual Budget. https://www.bahamasbudget.gov.bs/

(2) Revenue. https://www.bahamasbudget.gov.bs/numbers/revenue/

(3) Mid-year Budget Performance, 2020. https://www.bahamasbudget.gov.bs/media/filer_public/de/ff/defff07b-2b71-42c0-931f-b2bcef75f5d4/mid-year_budget_2020-21_final_1-compressed.pdf

indicators.justification: Interest and asset declaration information is unavailable online. According to the Public Disclosure Act, financial disclosures include information about income, assets, and liabilities, but no non-financial interests (for all public officials and their families or other intimates). These should be published as summary declarations in The Bahamas Official Gazette and therefore available to the public by contacting the Government Publications Department.

indicators.justification:
Unstructured procurement information is available from multiple websites. This information includes lower (goods and services) (1) and higher value (2) tenders (e.g. public works) with notices of award. The notices for the award of contract indicate that the process is governed by International Competitive Bidding (ICB) procedures (3). A wide range of agencies and departments submit tenders. All the tenders are from government departments or agencies so it is not clear local government use the procurement process. The data does not seem to be persistent because there are no links to archives.

Sources

(1) eProcurement and Supply Registry Portal. https://suppliers.gov.bs/bahamas/noticeSearchResults.html

(2) Government Tenders and Tender Notices. https://www.bahamas.gov.bs/wps/portal/public/Government%20Tender%20and%20Projects/Tender%20and%20Tender%20Notices/!ut/p/b1/vZTJjqMwFEW_pT4ghU0YlwyBMNjMENggQigSEgIkhOnrOy2V1IPU6U1X2ytLx-_qnWeZSIgdkVyz4VRm_am5Zpfv54RJ10BFgkBxSKUBA7TANgWb3ZIWpJ9A_ATAH5YAXt43SCIidvuYZKU7GpUNTqegV-PlYB_mWTw82mrWtfu0j4bNeJi37uKzK-6imC0Arbo5i9UmlqU-c3Ve79I1xyJcC6KvV7B1JbnTa2nHSdmaRTBNjmR5zEsQDZkWO5mP-9tqPKWFM2hqJ5pgKBrXVKfVhEGyB8GwY_U5zEi6KwdzplCdtctl8tUhv0j1wWzcE93aWziPmD-_fTp40eRfHEZE8hKhwCfwQjPeNnVBxE-M_amOHwKgQSC4HnQAhyHhEztApV41t9pyXtxqcTVUiRgtoQnNYESAdbGvINE0EYA6qDwS-xr0zETH4GhifocOihuIdKQsi_D29nugRfr8M1CCjBHQwAPUVweqtMU9TbG-LdAkUC34vwPX_1Wpalvgyzv85dFQzr-foU4kp339Pub1O3jneAbSLEfxHAMoimOJsIoZVr5ro7wJ0_b5HzD36S4J52h3trZAiC5dqMp1dTT80F5dyzJWBWFaF5gVJ97JrTke4aRpITbaCOZZXurW_lrIwFA9g3Ru0R73lCipg4GunbIakVce8fIImY_Lffrw6GYsEAwOSn3PuFVQzGT-MAann84m21fHzaOTj6md9R-WapHiDW3S-Xo1hcRp8skaC-NmP3LIZGv9cWrWjggBXvBN5vwOc2Rjspkj8w_lWhyntliItg4Gk3E5_PFjo6egb5RAjF0!/dl4/d5/L2dBISEvZ0FBIS9nQSEh/

indicators.justification:
There is isolated evidence that the Bahamian government is supporting data use. The government is or has established a number of data portals (1; 2) but these seem to be for increasing fiscal/trade efficiency rather than for generating data for re-use. There are  agencies/departments that allow data reuse (3; 4), but altogether this seems insufficient evidence that these efforts are a strategy for the reuse of data. Further to this point, the OECD's OURdata index (5) that assesses countries on data availability, accessibility, and government support of reuse, scores the Bahamas at 0.04. The lowest possible score on the index is 0 the highest is 1.

indicators.justification:
There is a current requirement for companies to disclose their beneficial ownership to authorities, and will some of this information is available to the public. The Companies Act (1) makes some information available for a fee, however, the more comprehensive information produced in accordance with the Register of Beneficial Ownership Act (2) is not available to the public. There are no exemptions to reporting the identity of natural persons but only specific government actors are privileged to this information. 
The latter framework clearly defines the types of entities that:
(1) must report their beneficial ownership
(2) covers both ownership and control (e.g., shares, rights 
    to profit) and control (e.g., voting rights, other 
    influence) held directly or indirectly, including 
    through informal agreements
(3) regular updates to changes in beneficial ownership the information is accurate (there is a verification 
    process) and timely
(4) information is reported for the all limited 
    companies in the country

Sources

(1) The Companies Act, 1992. http://laws.bahamas.gov.bs/cms/images/LEGISLATION/PRINCIPAL/1992/1992-0018/CompaniesAct_1.pdf

(2) Register of Beneficial Ownership Act, 2018. http://laws.bahamas.gov.bs/cms/images/LEGISLATION/PRINCIPAL/2018/2018-0038/RegisterofBeneficialOwnershipAct2018_1.pdf

indicators.justification:
The Statistical Act, 1973 (1) was the law in effect for the study period. It was last amended in 1987 and as such, predates much of the concerns about data and data management. While the Act only speaks in general terms about data quality and publication, it applies to all of the public sector. See Chapter 33, Section 4 (b) and (c):
(b) to collect, compile, analyse, abstract and publish statistical information relating to the commercial, industrial, agricultural, mining, social, financial, economic and general activities and conditions of The Bahamas;
(c) to collaborate with other Government departments, commissions, bodies incorporated directly by Parliament and other organizations, in the collection, compilation, analysis and publication of statistical records of or connected with those departments, commissions, bodies and organizations;
The Statistical Act, 2021 (2) reflects contemporary data concerns and international best practices.

Sources

(1) Statistical Act, 1973. http://laws.bahamas.gov.bs/cms/images/LEGISLATION/PRINCIPAL/1973/1973-0022/StatisticsAct_1.pdf

(2) The Statistical Act, 2021. https://bahamas.gov.bs/wps/wcm/connect/7b7e57eb-38df-41f4-8cc0-5538317bd272/Statistics+Bill+2021.pdf?MOD=AJPERES

indicators.justification: There is little evidence of a data sharing law/policy. However, it is unlikely that there are no policies or regulations because the country produces System of National Accounts (SNA) reports that requires data from all sectors in the formal economy and as such must involve government to government and business to government data sharing. Furthermore, the repealed (July 1, 2021) Statistical Act (1973) suggests that the Director of Statistics can collaborate with other government departments and organizations (Chapter 33, Section 4 (c)), which implies some form of data sharing.

indicators.justification:
The official language of The Bahamas is English, though this is not documented in its constitution (1). As such, all communication with government is in English. There does not seem to be any official effort on the part of government to communicate in Haitian creole for the benefit of the largest immigrant group in the country.
While the Statistics Act (2) does not refer to specific standards, the country produces SNA reports that are regulated by international standards (3).

indicators.justification:
The FAA does not stipulate that the public should receive published information about public finance (1). It only requires that Minster of Finance table a report of summary statements in Parliament. The Bahamas seems to be in the process of increasing government transparency as evident by the PFMA (2) and PDMA (3). These laws that came into effect after the study period outline in detail information that should explicitly be collected and published (on government websites). However, while these legislative changes do appear to increase accountability, there is no provision for structured or open data.

Sources

(1) Financial Administration and Audit Act, 2010. http://laws.bahamas.gov.bs/cms/images/LEGISLATION/PRINCIPAL/2010/2010-0026/FinancialAdministrationandAuditAct2010_1.pdf

(3) Public Debt Management Act, 2021. http://laws.bahamas.gov.bs/cms/images/LEGISLATION/PRINCIPAL/2021/2021-0006/PublicDebtManagementAct2021_1.pdf

indicators.justification:
There is a framework for disclosure and verification of interests and assets information (1). It requires financial disclosures from all public officials, their partners, family members. Financial disclosures are published as summaries but the extent of public access is unclear. Access may be limited to state actors, as Smith (2) writes that the Public Disclosure Commission Chairman refused to name non-compliant ministers of government for 2020, as well as whether they were repeat offenders. The framework empowers an agency to ensure the accurate, 
timely collection and publication of required information, and updated annually and is responsive to changes in employment.

(1) The Public Disclosure Act, 1977. http://laws.bahamas.gov.bs/cms/images/LEGISLATION/PRINCIPAL/1976/1976-0012/PublicDisclosureAct_1.pdf

(2) 'Less than 10' parliamentarians miss disclosure deadline, 2020. https://ewnews.com/less-than-10-parliamentarians-miss-disclosure-deadline

indicators.justification:

indicators.justification:
The existing act governing parliamentary elections does not address campaign finances (1). The Act and IDEA assessment (2) is presented as evidence. The Integrity Commission Bill addresses some gaps in public access to information to campaign funding of political parties but it yet to be debated as evidenced by the Eyewitness News report (3).

(3) Campaign finance a necessity as we enter 'silly season', says ORG, 2020. https://ewnews.com/campaign-finance-a-necessity-as-we-enter-silly-season-says-org

indicators.justification:
Government ministries and agencies use public consultations in regulatory matters as is evidenced by the EIAR (1). However, this does not seem to be the standard operating procedure (2). As such, it seems that the need for the collection and publication of data related to public consultation have largely not been considered.

indicators.justification:
The Freedom of Information Act (1) requires the collection of RTI performance information. This data is obtained from the government ministries and/or agencies and be reported to Parliament by the Information Commissioner. Though most of this information contains desired details, it is unlikely to be available as structured data because the FIOA does contain that stipulation.

Sources

(1) The Freedom of Information Act, 2017. http://laws.bahamas.gov.bs/cms/images/LEGISLATION/PRINCIPAL/2017/2017-0001/FreedomofInformationAct2017_1.pdf

indicators.justification: There is no evidence of any Bahamian services that uses company information to do due diligence. There is at least one non-Bahamian services that offer services that seem to use company information from the Bahamian government's company search service. This is a paid service that is provided for the private sector. It seems to limited to extracts of company information that does include some beneficial ownership information but is unlikely to constitute a KYC analysis. The utility of the service is unclear.

indicators.justification:
There is no verifiable evidence of civil society organizations using data in this way.

The HRB in the Eyewitness News article mentions land titles but this is not enough evidence to indicate the use of information from the Land Register (1). The article does suggest, however, that the government is engaged in using land tenure as an exclusionary tool.

The draft of The National Development Plan (2) outlines a strategy for the reform of land administration. It should portend the use of land data by the government to guide the reform process.

indicators.justification:
It is difficult to argue that political integrity data is being used by social groups to highlight government failures because the government does not collect this information (much of it not require by law (1)). Because of the lack of data on political integrity data, social groups are forced to use the absence of such data and difficult to substantiate information as the evidence of abuse. While that is clearly a problem, it is difficult to argue that these groups are using political integrity data to hold government accountable. Bahamians believe that corruption is a problem but this has not been substantiated in concrete terms, just controversies or scandals (2). To this effect, it seems that the accused are often acquitted (3). 

Sources

(1) Campaign finance a necessity as we enter 'silly season', says ORG, 2020. https://ewnews.com/campaign-finance-a-necessity-as-we-enter-silly-season-says-org

(2) NOT A GOOD LOOK": Historian says this is the most Cabinet resignations since 1984 corruption report, 2021. https://ewnews.com/not-a-good-look-historian-says-this-is-the-most-cabinet-resignations-since-1984-corruption-report

(3) Shane Gibson found not guilty in bribery trial, 2019. https://ewnews.com/shane-gibson-found-not-guilty-in-bribery-trial
